segments.text: I was in the Bureau of Mines in the fairly early 30s.
At that time, we had a station in Pittsburgh.
It was on the grounds of the Kearney Institute up there, and it was a comparatively small station.
But there was a man by the name of Storch.
Oh, yes, H.H.
Storch.
H.H.
Storch and several of his associates who had been, Lester Hurst, for example, who had been doing
laboratory work on coal hydrogenation for a long, long time.
And the publications on that are still available.
Many of them I have here.
But this was all really small-scale autoclave work.
It was, in essence, a duplication of a lot of the research work that the Germans had carried out before they built their plants in Germany.
And that work continued through the, until about 1940.
In 1940, I was transferred from experimental work to the Washington office and became assistant director of the fuels and explosive service under a man by the name of Dr. Fielder.
we probably haven't run into on this yet.
But he had a very active part in really getting synthetic fuel work started in Jeremiah.
And about that time, the Secretary of Interior, Harold Ickes, and his assistants became interested in synthetic fuel work.
And then in 1941, as you remember, we got in the war with Japan and the war with the European powers.
And during that war, the Allies furnished most of the oil for Europe because they were cut off from any other sources of oil and they lost the Romanian oil and so on and so forth.
Mike Strauss, who was then one of the assistant secretaries,

became very active with beer mines, and as the war went on, about 1942 or 1943, he proposed that the beer mines start a more vigorous and enlarged program on synthetic fuels on the basis that maybe at the end of the war we might need synthetic fuels as a possible source for oil.
Thank you.
The...
The Secretary's office got over to Congress, and they talked to a number of congressmen.
In particular, we might mention Senator O'Mahony from Wyoming and Congressman Randolph from West Virginia.
Congressman Randolph is now Senator Randolph, by the way.
And Murdoch.
from Utah, and Gurney, I don't remember his first name.
I believe he's from North Dakota.
And what was his first name, Edward?
I forgot.
And these senators became interested.
And then the secretary's office suggested to Bureau of Mines that we make a trip to, this was wartime by then, it was about 1942.
And they suggested that we make a trip to England to study the coal hydrogenation work that the English had done at Billingham.
And in fact, they had a sizable plant operating at Billingham on the hydrogenation of coal and tar.
So H.H.
Storch, Dr. Storch, and I went to England and spent about a month with the English people, mostly at Billingham and related facilities.
And they, very, very kind to us, revealed much of the data they had accumulated on building this big plant.
And as a matter of fact, the large plant was designed almost specifically after the German coal hydrogenation plants.
And we came back to this country, and then the senators thought that we should make a tour of a number of states and begin to try to acquaint people in a general way
with not only with coal hydrogenation, but with the Fischer-Tropsch process as well.

There were no Fischer-Tropsch plants in existence outside of Germany at that time, but we had a good deal of information about the Fischer-Tropsch process and had worked on it in the Bureau of Mines as well.
So there was a senatorial group got together and
We went down to West Virginia.
We went to Pittsburgh.
And they gave speeches and talks.
And then we went out west to Sheridan, Wyoming, where Senator O'Mahony was an influential man.
And we went to Utah.
And we toured several other states, trying to generate some interest in the synthetic floor.
And as a result of that, there was passed the Synthetic Fuel Act.
I believe it was of 1944, but don't hold me to that.
That's correct.
It was 1944.
And that provided funds, up to a good many million dollars, to investigate synthetic fuels.

And about the time this act was passed, we started work to build laboratories at Brewston, Pennsylvania, which is now called PERC, by the way, and the Morgantown Laboratory at Morgantown, West Virginia, which is now called MERC, M-E-R-C. And we built the Louisiana, Missouri.
Louisiana, Missouri is about 85 miles north of St. Louis on the Mississippi River.
We started to build a demonstration plant for the coal hydrogenation operations and a smaller Fisher-Tropsch plant for the Fisher-Tropsch operations.
We also undertook the building of the oil shale plant at Rifle, Colorado, and built the laboratory at Laramie, Wyoming, which is the oil shale laboratory.
All of that was really done under that particular act.
But as we began to go into our development work on these projects, the war was drawing to a close.
And you asked me briefly about the various teams that went over to Germany to investigate the German industry.
Now, there were a good many of those teams dealing with chemicals and various aspects of German industry.
The one we were interested in, of course, was called the oil team, really, and dealt with oil and synthetic fuels both.
And I guess probably it comprised from 150 to 200 people, but not necessarily all at once.
I mean, they went at various times and they came back at various times, so it was rather an indeterminate group at any one time.
But those people were selected.
They were largely either from the government, mainly from the Bureau of Mines or

other groups in the government who had been doing work with oil or synthetic fuels, or they were from the oil industry itself, from practically all the oil companies, all the major oil companies certainly sent one or more people to take part in these investigations.

And there were also people from some of the coal companies and people from companies like coppers and so on and so forth who had connections in foreign countries and who had worked in this field in one way or another.
As I remember it, that organization went along all during the latter part of 1944 and then during the

In the early part of 1945, during January and February, various groups of these individuals were transferred to London and then from London went into the field to learn what we could as soon as the German army was driven out of the plants and we could get in and begin our investigations.
As far as synthetic fuels is concerned,
I will not treat the oil industry because this is a different topic, really, and I don't think we need to bring it in at this point.
As far as synthetic fuels was concerned, we were particularly interested.
There were 12 coal hydrogenation plants, and I suppose on the average they ran around 5,000 to 7,000 or 8,000 barrels a day.
Not all these plants were available because some were in the Russian zones, but I guess we visited and studied about eight of these cohydrogenation plants.
And if my memory serves correctly, there were about seven Fischer-Tropsch plants.
And I believe that we visited essentially all of those.
As I remember, the fish and trophy plants were pretty much in the zones that we could get at, so we also got a chance to look at the fish and trophy plants.
They were smaller plants, in general running around 2,000 barrels a day of fuel.
Now, in addition to that, of course,
As you know, the Germans were always strong in coal technology, and they had a group of laboratories who had been doing coal technology work, I guess, for 15 or 20 years.
And we visited all those laboratories and, in fact, tried to talk to all the people that we knew of that had been instrumental in coal work.
And in addition to that, we visited a lot of other concerns.
For instance, people who had been doing gasification work, like Lurgy.
And Lurgy had been interested in gasification, I guess, since the early 1930s.
And then we visited people like Coppers,
Later on, developed the coprostatic process for gasification, which you've probably heard about.
The groups were divided up into sort of working teams, and at any one time you might...
You might have involved in a team two people or four people or probably six people, usually not many more than that.
And they were assigned targets, and they selected these targets.
By the way, I was in general a leader of the team, although I wasn't always in a position where I could do much leading because I was in the field a lot.
But we tried to divide this work up and assign it to people who were most knowledgeable in these fields.

And the thing evolved without any trouble at all because these were highly skilled and highly knowledgeable people, and they knew very much about what they wanted to see when they went over there, and they learned a great deal more.
And so they in themselves were capable of more or less picking out their targets and going there and doing the investigation.
And we might spend...
If it were a laboratory or something like that, we might spend two or three days at it.
If it were a plant, we might spend a week or more at it.
And oftentimes, two or three teams investigated various aspects of a plant because...
Excuse me, I'm going to let you interrupt.
Yeah, I have a couple of questions I want to ask for my purposes.
If you went into a plant, you went completely through it mechanically as well as checking its records?
Yes, we did.
We tried to accumulate as much of the records as we could.
And wherever possible, we made notes from those records.
And in some cases, we could get copies of the records.
And all of those things were compiled and brought back to London or to Brussels.
A lot of this work was done out of Brussels.
And each time we investigated a target, we wrote a report out of it.
It was a CIOS report, chaos we often call it.
Some people call it chaos, but this was a matter of choice, I guess.
And those reports were all eventually brought back here.
They were compiled and edited by the Bureau of Mines and various other groups, by the oil industry and so on and so forth.
And eventually, the Department of Commerce set up a sort of a central location that was to do printing and reproduction of those, but what happened to all those reports, I can't tell you.
We have them all.
We have the BIOS, the SIOS, and the FIAT.
Well, I'm glad to know that, because I may need some of these myself before this thing goes too far.
What about field notes?
Did you save your field notes, I wonder?
Oh, no.
As far as I know, we didn't.
We wrote
final, what we called final reports, and as far as I know, I never saved my field notes, and I don't know if other people did save their field notes.
This accumulated to quite a lot of paper as time went on, you know, and we were very limited.
See, we were working in the field, and houses were all torn down, and we were living under very difficult and strenuous conditions, and so on and so forth.
Most of our writing we did in Brussels and London, really.
Now, any other questions?
Oh, yeah.
Fire away.
Yes, I have a whole bunch.
What first interested you in synthetic fuels?
Why are you in the Bureau of Mines in 1939?
That's awfully early to be interested in synthetic fuels.
Well, the Bureau of Mines, as you probably know, was originally established really to control and investigate and guide and help the mining industry
And out of that grew a great desire to improve and modify the utilization of coal.
And my first interest, actually, was in water conditioning.
But then I became more and more immersed in hydrocarbon chemistry.
By the time 1935 and 1936 was around, I was pretty much involved with oil and coal chemistry.
Then I went in to work with Dr. Filner, and this was the fuels and explosives service.
I had little to do with the explosive ends of it, but all of my work was on the fuels ends, which included coal and petroleum.

I think at that time that there was always a feeling in the Bureau of Mines that since we had such enormous reserves of coal, and since we didn't really know how much oil we had or even how long those reserves might last, that we should look forward and begin the investigation of coal
and particularly with the possibility of converting coal to oil and gas.
Now, I think at this point you ought to understand one or two things about the chemistry of coal.
The difference between coal and oil from the viewpoint of ultimate analysis, that is the amount of carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen they contain,

is that oil runs around 8%, 10%, or 11% hydrogen, the rest of it being mainly carbon, while coal is about half that much hydrogen, the rest of it being mainly carbon, but that there are other elements in coal like sulfur and oxygen and ash and so on and so forth.
So the thought has always been, and this was true of the Germans, and it was true of all the people in Europe, and it was true of our own chemists here.
Our basic idea was that if we could add about 5% or 6% hydrogen to a whole particle, we could, in fact, convert it to liquid.
And this doesn't sound like a very difficult job, does it?
It sounds easy.
I think it was these, and 80% of our hydrocarbon reserves are certainly in the form of coal.
So there was every reason for the United States to begin to point itself in the direction of making oil from coal on first
a basis that we might ultimately run out of oil or get low on oil, and second, maybe it offered economic possibilities.
Now, the economic possibilities have been difficult to find and are still difficult to find, but we may face the prospect that we have to use our coal reserves to help supplement our oil reserves.
And this was the basis that the Bureau of Mines got in on this thing.
And this explains why you're involved in it so early.
And I got involved in it, as I say, about 37 or 38, and my interest in it has been almost continuous since that time.
The first time we picked you up in our work, we have you identified in explosives.
Now, how did we come up with that?
That was because I was assistant chief of the fuels and explosives service.
But I have done very little in explosives, really.
And I take it technically, then, you were not ever really in the Army.
Technically, we were only put into the Army as experts, not as full Army.
I was never really awe werewhat did they call us?
Simulated colonels or something like that.
I've forgotten what
But we actually wore uniforms over there and so on and so forth.
But I had no Army training nor no Army pay or anything else.
Now, when the Germans are interviewed, they can't really distinguish between yourselves and soldiers.
That is true.
They really think that they're being interviewed by the US Army all the way through.
I had never thought of that, but I think that is.
So that means a sizable number of the people involved in Tom then were civilians.
And not military personnel?
Well, they were all.
Everybody was a civilian.
I wonder if any list of those people were ever compiled.
Yeah, I'm sure there were lists of them.
But where you'd find them, I don't know.
I could probably tell you 50 of them if I sat here and thought a while about it.
And if you go through those reels and reports, you'll find they're all authors of those reports.
Now, those people are essentially all civilians.
Now, there was another group of people over there.
There was a Navy team under Captain Pettyjohn who also did a lot of interviewing, and there was some rivalry between these two groups.
It wasn't serious, but there was some rivalry.
Now, he's retired to Florida.
Yes, I think you're right.
Sarasota, Florida, that's the man we are.
Yeah, you want to talk to Petty John.
Sarasota, Florida, of course.
This probably will give you a little explanation of how this came about.
Now, I would like to say this about the Germans.
As far as the upper class of German technical people that we knew, that we dealt with over there,

many of those we had corresponded with before the war and many of those people knew that we were scientists and not soldiers in any way shape or form you know and uh it was a it was a rather strange situation uh uh we went over and talked to people like dr hoobman from lurgy and payer pier from uh from uh
IG Farman and people like that, they knew us well from previous correspondence.
And there was no problem, no animosity between the groups that were involved in most cases at all.
And I had no feeling, really, that I was a soldier of a conquered country or anything like that.
And I think 99% of our people would have never even thought of that, you know.
It was just colleagues?
We were scientists speaking to scientists.
That was the story.
And that we happened to be on one side and they happened to be on another side, probably it was incidental to the whole...
Were the Germans further ahead in technology than you anticipated them being?
Well, no, I don't think so.
In the sense that we had read about their technology and knew about their technology, but...
The truth is that we had no real plant technology on synthetic fuels in this country.
We had laboratory technology.
But they were the only ones who really had gone ahead with this plant technology.
Now, as the investigations went on, we got into every aspect of this.
And as you realize, these are very complex and very large, very complex plants, very high pressure plants.
And so we had had teams which dealt with preparing the coal for the plants, feeding the coal to the plants, generating hydrogen for the plants, the hydrogenation step itself, and so on and so forth.
So there were dozens of reports that would cover various aspects of the whole operation.
We were well into this, and this investigation ran over a period of about six to eight months.
Actually, we got into Germany.
I think the first trip I made to Germany was either January or February.
Oh, you were in there even as the Allied armies were pouring in.
Yes, before the war was over.
And in fact, we were into Rhein-Preuysen, which was one of the Fisch-Tropsch plans.
The Germans were still on the other side of the river.
There were still shells coming into the plants.
Not heavily.
I wouldn't say we were in any danger or anything like that.
But we were investigating in there.
And in the evenings, trying to write reports and get our notes together and organize as best we could.
That was early.
Early 1945, because it was cold, the buildings were no heat in the buildings and no water to take a bath or anything like that, we did the best we could.
That's all there was to it.
And the investigations then went on to about the middle or the autumn of that year after the war was over, and reports were still being issued.
I stayed there until about...
I guess about June.
I remember when Roosevelt died and Truman took over.
I listened to that speech in London.
And then a couple of weeks later, I came back.
So that would have been the latter part of May that I came back.
Now, I ought to mention one other thing that was two or three other things that were done.
We collected all the data and documents that we possibly could from the German plants.
We wrote all the reports that we could, and oftentimes the teams that got together and analyzed these reports and made comments and suggestions for
for revisions, although under conditions like this, you can't go into a detailed report.
You do the best you can with the time and effort that you've got available.
And then, as the end of this investigating period approached, I don't know where the suggestion came from, but it had generated, I think, in a number of areas,
We thought that it might be a good idea to enlist the German engineers who had designed and worked in the plants and built the plants to actually write up their own story in German.
And I think this effort was paid for and organized by the Air Force, as I remember it.
those people, the German people, then did set down and write up for the Air Force.
And I believe these reports came out of Dayton.
Or where is the Air Force?
Right, that's in Dayton.
That's the Air Force Institute of Technology.
And some of those, particularly those reports, were excellent on coal hydrogenation.
And...
I can't put my finger on mine at the moment because they may be moved over here, but there were about 10 or 12 of those reports on coal hydrogenation that were
I'm sure I've got them.
Here's Bureau of Mines publication on synthetic liquid fuel.
No, those were our own publications, and I have those here.
But the German part, they're in black covers.
Reports to the Department of Engineering Research.

oh here they are I was looking for them watch your oh I'm watching watch your I believe there were eight or ten volumes of that but this is one of the volumes you know and some of them dealt with chemistry and some of them dealt with engineering and some of them dealt with metallurgy and some of them dealt with the plant structures and so on and so forth
And then they were all translated into English.
And you ought to have copies of those documents.
Oh, we'll get them.
We'll get them.
We'll get them.
You ought to have copies of those documents.
We'll find a way to... Let me ask you, while I'm looking at this, would you say that these charts indicate the reasonably accurate structure of how the organization was developed?
How are you going to take all these tapes?
Well, you take a couple dozen tapes this time.
I was going to get about $2,500.
That would be too boxy.
How do you get on a beep when you have a minute left?
I don't know how many feet run through there.
Because if it beeps at the end, I mean, you can be halfway through a word.
Better, I guess, than not even knowing it stopped.
You've got time.
You've got to open it a little.
in that interview with Walton Smith.
My gosh, the belly.
